questions.notes: A common assumption among art historians is that the invention of photography in the mid-nineteenth century displaced the painted portrait in the public consciousness. The diminishing popularity of the portrait miniature, which coincided with the rise of photography, seems to support this claim. However, photography’s impact on the portrait miniature may be overstated. Although records from art exhibitions in the Netherlands from 1820 to 1892 show a decrease in the number of both full-sized and miniature portraits submitted, this trend was established before the invention of photography.
questions.question: Based on the text, what can be concluded about the diminishing popularity of the portrait miniature in the nineteenth century?

answer_choices.A: Factors other than the rise of photography may be more directly responsible for the portrait miniature’s decline.
answer_choices.B: Although portrait miniatures became less common than photographs, they were widely regarded as having more artistic merit.
answer_choices.C: The popularity of the portrait miniature likely persisted for longer than art historians have assumed.
answer_choices.D: As demand for portrait miniatures decreased, portrait artists likely shifted their creative focus to photography.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The text indicates that the impact of photography might be overstated since the decline in portrait miniatures began before photography’s invention, implying that other factors may have driven the decline.

questions.notes: Believing that living in an impractical space can heighten awareness and even improve health, conceptual artists Madeline Gins and Shusaku Arakawa designed an apartment building in Japan to be more fanciful than functional. A kitchen counter is chest-high on one side and knee-high on the other; a ceiling has a door to nowhere. The effect is disorienting but invigorating: after four years there, filmmaker Nobu Yamaoka reported significant health benefits.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Although inhabiting a home surrounded by fanciful features such as those designed by Gins and Arakawa can be rejuvenating, it is unsustainable.
answer_choices.B: Designing disorienting spaces like those in the Gins and Arakawa building is the most effective way to create a physically stimulating environment.
answer_choices.C: As a filmmaker, Yamaoka has long supported the designs of conceptual artists such as Gins and Arakawa.
answer_choices.D: Although impractical, the design of the apartment building by Gins and Arakawa may improve the well-being of the apartment building’s residents.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it accurately reflects that despite the building’s impractical design, it has the potential to improve the residents' well-being, as supported by Yamaoka’s reported health benefits.

questions.notes: The most recent iteration of the immersive theater experience Sleep No More, which premiered in New York City in 2011, transforms its performance space—a five-story warehouse—into a 1930s-era hotel. Audience members, who wander through the labyrinthine venue at their own pace and follow the actors as they play out simultaneous, interweaving narrative loops, confront the impossibility of experiencing the production in its entirety. The play’s refusal of narrative coherence thus hinges on the sense of spatial fragmentation that the venue’s immense and intricate layout generates.
questions.question: What does the text most strongly suggest about Sleep No More’s use of its performance space?

answer_choices.A: The choice of a New York City venue likely enabled the play’s creators to experiment with the use of theatrical space in a way that venues from earlier productions could not.
answer_choices.B: Audience members likely find the experience of the play disappointing because they generally cannot make their way through the entire venue.
answer_choices.C: The production’s dependence on a particular performance environment would likely make it difficult to reproduce exactly in a different theatrical space.
answer_choices.D: Audience members who navigate the space according to a recommended itinerary will likely have a better grasp of the play’s narrative than audience members who depart from that itinerary.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. The text emphasizes that the production’s effect relies heavily on the unique, intricate layout of its performance space, implying that replicating the production in another space would be challenging.

questions.notes: Utah is home to Pando, a colony of about 47,000 quaking aspen trees that all share a single root system. Pando is one of the largest single organisms by mass on Earth, but ecologists are worried that its growth is declining in part because of grazing by animals. The ecologists say that strong fences could prevent deer from eating young trees and help Pando start thriving again.
questions.question: According to the text, why are ecologists worried about Pando?

answer_choices.A: It isn’t growing at the same rate it used to.
answer_choices.B: It isn’t producing young trees anymore.
answer_choices.C: It can’t grow into new areas because it is blocked by fences.
answer_choices.D: Its root system can’t support many more new trees.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text states that ecologists are concerned that Pando’s growth is declining—implying that it is not growing at the rate it once did.

questions.notes:
The following text is from Jane Austen’s 1811 novel Sense and Sensibility. Elinor lives with her younger sisters and her mother, Mrs. Dashwood.
Elinor, this eldest daughter, whose advice was so effectual, possessed a strength of understanding, and coolness of judgment, which qualified her, though only nineteen, to be the counsellor of her mother, and enabled her frequently to counteract, to the advantage of them all, that eagerness of mind in Mrs. Dashwood which must generally have led to imprudence. She had an excellent heart;—her disposition was affectionate, and her feelings were strong; but she knew how to govern them: it was a knowledge which her mother had yet to learn; and which one of her sisters had resolved never to be taught.
questions.question: According to the text, what is true about Elinor?

answer_choices.A: Elinor often argues with her mother but fails to change her mind.
answer_choices.B: Elinor can be overly sensitive with regard to family matters.
answer_choices.C: Elinor thinks her mother is a bad role model.
answer_choices.D: Elinor is remarkably mature for her age.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text highlights that, despite being only nineteen, Elinor possesses a high level of understanding and judgment, making her exceptionally mature.

questions.notes: Biologists have predicted that birds’ feather structures vary with habitat temperature, but this hadn’t been tested in mountain environments. Ornithologist Sahas Barve studied feathers from 249 songbird species inhabiting different elevations—and thus experiencing different temperatures—in the Himalaya Mountains. He found that feathers of high-elevation species not only have a greater proportion of warming downy sections to flat and smooth sections than do feathers of low-elevation species, but high-elevation species’ feathers also tend to be longer, providing a thicker layer of insulation.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Barve’s investigation shows that some species of Himalayan songbirds have evolved feathers that better regulate body temperature than do the feathers of other species, contradicting previous predictions.
answer_choices.B: Barve found an association between habitat temperature and feather structure among Himalayan songbirds, lending new support to a general prediction.
answer_choices.C: Barve discovered that songbirds have adapted to their environment by growing feathers without flat and smooth sections, complicating an earlier hypothesis.
answer_choices.D: The results of Barve’s study suggest that the ability of birds to withstand cold temperatures is determined more strongly by feather length than feather structure, challenging an established belief.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text describes an association between habitat temperature and feather structure among Himalayan songbirds, thereby lending support to the general prediction that birds’ feather structures vary with habitat temperature.

questions.notes: Paleontologists searching for signs of ancient life have found many fossilized specimens of prehistoric human ancestors, including several from the Pleistocene era discovered in a geological formation in the Minatogawa quarry in Japan. However, to study the emergence of the earliest multicellular organisms to appear on Earth, researchers must turn elsewhere, such as to the Ediacaran geological formation at Mistaken Point in Canada. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the 146-hectare reserve contains more than 10,000 fossils that together document a critical moment in evolutionary history.
questions.question: What does the text indicate about the geological formation at Mistaken Point?

answer_choices.A: It holds a greater number of fossils but from a smaller variety of species than the formation in the Minatogawa quarry does.
answer_choices.B: It has provided evidence that the earliest human species may have emerged before the Pleistocene era.
answer_choices.C: It is widely considered by paleontologists to be the most valuable source of information about prehistoric life forms.
answer_choices.D: It contains specimens from an older time period than those found in the formation in the Minatogawa quarry.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. The text explains that Mistaken Point preserves fossils of the earliest multicellular organisms, implying that these fossils date from an older period than the Pleistocene-era fossils found at the Minatogawa quarry.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Johanna Spyri’s 1881 novel Heidi (translated by Elisabeth Stork in 1915). Eight-year-old Heidi and her friend’s grandmother are looking at some illustrated books.
Heidi had come and was looking with wondering eyes at the splendid pictures in the large books, that Grandmama was showing her. Suddenly she screamed aloud, for there on the picture she saw a peaceful flock grazing on a green pasture. In the middle a shepherd was standing, leaning on his crook. The setting sun was shedding a golden light over everything. With glowing eyes Heidi devoured the scene.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Heidi is upset until she sees a serene image of a pasture in one of Grandmama’s books.
answer_choices.B: Heidi is delighted and fascinated by an image she sees in one of Grandmama’s books.
answer_choices.C: Heidi is initially frightened by an image in one of Grandmama’s books but quickly comes to appreciate its beauty.
answer_choices.D: Heidi is inspecting an image in one of Grandmama’s books because she has never seen a shepherd with his sheep before.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text shows that Heidi reacts with delight and fascination when she sees the peaceful, radiant image of the pasture.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Edgar Allan Poe’s 1849 story “Landor’s Cottage.”
During a pedestrian trip last summer, through one or two of the river counties of New York, I found myself, as the day declined, somewhat embarrassed about the road I was pursuing. The land undulated very remarkably; and my path, for the last hour, had wound about and about so confusedly, in its effort to keep in the valleys, that I no longer knew in what direction lay the sweet village of B——, where I had determined to stop for the night.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: The narrator remembers a trip he took and admits to getting lost.
answer_choices.B: The narrator recalls fond memories of a journey that he took through some beautiful river counties.
answer_choices.C: The narrator describes what he saw during a long trip through a frequently visited location.
answer_choices.D: The narrator explains the difficulties he encountered on a trip and how he overcame them.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. The narrator expresses embarrassment over his confused, winding path that ultimately left him lost as he sought his destination.

questions.notes: In 1934, physicist Eugene Wigner posited the existence of a crystal consisting entirely of electrons in a honeycomb-like structure. The so-called Wigner crystal remained largely conjecture, however, until Feng Wang and colleagues announced in 2021 that they had captured an image of one. The researchers trapped electrons between two semiconductors and then cooled the apparatus, causing the electrons to settle into a crystalline structure. By inserting an ultrathin sheet of graphene above the crystal, the researchers obtained an impression—the first visual confirmation of the Wigner crystal.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Researchers have obtained the most definitive evidence to date of the existence of the Wigner crystal.
answer_choices.B: Researchers have identified an innovative new method for working with unusual crystalline structures.
answer_choices.C: Graphene is the most important of the components required to capture an image of a Wigner crystal.
answer_choices.D: It’s difficult to acquire an image of a Wigner crystal because of the crystal’s honeycomb structure.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because the text details how the long-hypothesized Wigner crystal was finally confirmed visually through a novel experimental method.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from María Cristina Mena’s 1914 short story “The Vine-Leaf.”
It is a saying in the capital of Mexico that Dr. Malsufrido carries more family secrets under his hat than any archbishop. The doctor’s hat is, appropriately enough, uncommonly capacious, rising very high, and sinking so low that it seems to be supported by his ears and eyebrows, and it has a furry look, as if it had been brushed the wrong way, which is perhaps what happens to it if it is ever brushed at all. When the doctor takes it off, the family secrets do not fly out like a flock of parrots, but remain nicely bottled up beneath a dome of old and highly polished ivory.
questions.question: Based on the text, how do people in the capital of Mexico most likely regard Dr. Malsufrido?

answer_choices.A: Many have come to tolerate him despite his disheveled appearance.
answer_choices.B: Few feel concerned that he will divulge their confidences.
answer_choices.C: Some dislike how freely he discusses his own family.
answer_choices.D: Most would be unimpressed by him were it not for his professional expertise.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text uses a humorous metaphor to suggest that Dr. Malsufrido keeps secrets well, so people do not worry about their confidences being revealed.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Countee Cullen’s 1926 poem “Thoughts in a Zoo.”
They in their cruel traps, and we in ours, 
Survey each other’s rage, and pass the hours 
Commiserating each the other’s woe, 
To mitigate his own pain’s fiery glow. 
Man could but little proffer in exchange 
Save that his cages have a larger range. 
That lion with his lordly, untamed heart 
Has in some man his human counterpart, 
Some lofty soul in dreams and visions wrapped, 
But in the stifling flesh securely trapped.
questions.question: Based on the text, what challenge do humans sometimes experience?

answer_choices.A: They cannot effectively tame certain wild animals because of a lack of compassion.
answer_choices.B: They cannot focus on setting attainable goals because of a lack of motivation.
answer_choices.C: They quickly become frustrated when faced with difficult tasks because of a lack of self-control.
answer_choices.D: They have aspirations that cannot be fulfilled because of certain limitations.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. The text metaphorically compares humans to animals in cages, suggesting that despite lofty aspirations, humans are limited by physical and societal constraints.

questions.notes: In superfluorescence, electrical charges known as dipoles emit light in synchronized bursts so intense that they are visible to the eye. Until recently, this phenomenon has only been observed at extremely cold temperatures because dipoles cannot synchronize at higher temperatures. But in a study, Melike Biliroglu and colleagues observed superfluorescence at room temperature in thin films made of perovskite and other similarly crystalline materials; the researchers propose that the formation of shock-absorbing quasiparticles called polarons in the material protects dipoles from thermal interference.
questions.question: Based on the text, how are polarons believed to be involved in the superfluorescence observed in Biliroglu and colleagues’ study?

answer_choices.A: Polarons enable superfluorescent bursts to cross from one crystalline material to another.
answer_choices.B: Polarons allow for the dipoles to synchronize despite higher temperatures.
answer_choices.C: Polarons accelerate the dipoles’ release of superfluorescent bursts.
answer_choices.D: Polarons decrease the intensity of the superfluorescent burst.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text explains that polarons help protect dipoles from thermal interference, allowing them to synchronize at room temperature and produce superfluorescence.

questions.notes: Scent is tightly interwoven with our daily lives, often evoking significant memories and important social events. This connection is of growing interest to archaeologists who hope to use it to better understand ancient rituals, trade, social hierarchies, and medicine. Although the speed at which odor molecules dissipate makes identifying ancient scents challenging, advancements in biomolecular technologies show promise in unlocking ancient aromas from preserved artifacts. Archaeological studies making use of these advancements may provide new insights into past societies.
questions.question: According to the text, what is one reason some archaeologists are interested in recovering scents from ancient artifacts?

answer_choices.A: They are investigating whether people’s sense of smell has declined in recent centuries.
answer_choices.B: They believe the scents could illuminate important aspects of ancient life.
answer_choices.C: They think that ancient scents would be enjoyable to people today.
answer_choices.D: They hope to develop new medicines using ancient scent molecules.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. The text explains that archaeologists want to recover scents because these scents can offer insights into ancient rituals, trade, social hierarchies, and medicine—key aspects of ancient life.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Edith Nesbit’s 1906 novel The Railway Children.
Mother did not spend all her time in paying dull [visits] to dull ladies, and sitting dully at home waiting for dull ladies to pay [visits] to her. She was almost always there, ready to play with the children, and read to them, and help them to do their home-lessons. Besides this she used to write stories for them while they were at school, and read them aloud after tea, and she always made up funny pieces of poetry for their birthdays and for other great occasions.
questions.question: According to the text, what is true about Mother?

answer_choices.A: She wishes that more ladies would visit her.
answer_choices.B: Birthdays are her favorite special occasion.
answer_choices.C: She creates stories and poems for her children.
answer_choices.D: Reading to her children is her favorite activity.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text clearly mentions that Mother writes stories and makes up funny poetry for her children, highlighting her creative role in their lives.

questions.notes: Paleontologist Lucas E. Fiorelli and colleagues have reported the discovery at a mine in Brazil of several egg clutches, partially preserved single eggs, and egg shells from the Late Cretaceous period. The researchers have concluded that the area was once a nesting and breeding site for titanosaurs, a group of sauropod dinosaurs. The finding is significant given the previous lack of known nesting sites in northern regions of South America, which led many paleontologists to assume that titanosaurs migrated south to lay eggs.
questions.question: What does the text most strongly suggest about the site discovered by the researchers?

answer_choices.A: It is the earliest known example of a titanosaur nesting and breeding site.
answer_choices.B: It was very difficult to excavate given that it was discovered in a mine.
answer_choices.C: It may have been occupied by other sauropods in addition to titanosaurs.
answer_choices.D: It is farther north than any other nesting site discovered in South America.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because the text emphasizes that the significance of the discovery lies in the fact that nesting sites in northern South America were previously unknown, indicating that this site is situated farther north than other known sites.

questions.notes: Philadelphia’s Black Pearl Chamber Orchestra, founded by Jeri Lynne Johnson, performs classical music, from well-known compositions by Beethoven to contemporary works by Jessie Montgomery. For the orchestra’s iConduct! program, Johnson invites community members to learn some basic elements of conducting and then experience conducting the Black Pearl orchestra themselves.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: The Black Pearl orchestra performs music from all over the world but mostly performs music composed by Philadelphians.
answer_choices.B: Johnson founded the Black Pearl orchestra to perform classical music by contemporary artist Jessie Montgomery.
answer_choices.C: The Black Pearl orchestra gives community members the chance to both listen to and participate in classical music performance.
answer_choices.D: Johnson has community members conduct an orchestra to demonstrate how difficult the task is.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text highlights that the orchestra not only performs classical music but also provides an opportunity for community members to learn about and engage with conducting, thus combining listening and active participation.

questions.notes: Several scholars have argued that conditions in England in the late ninth through early eleventh centuries—namely, burgeoning literacy amid running conflicts between England’s Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and Danish invaders—were especially conducive to the production of the Old English epic poem Beowulf, and they have dated the poem’s composition accordingly. It is not inconceivable that Beowulf emerged from such a context, but privileging contextual fit over the linguistic evidence of an eighth- or even seventh-century composition requires a level of justification that thus far has not been presented.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: Although there are some grounds for believing that Beowulf was composed between the late ninth and early eleventh centuries, advocates for that view tend to rely on evidence that has been called into question by advocates for an earlier date.
answer_choices.B: Although several scholars have dated Beowulf to the late ninth through early eleventh centuries, others have argued that doing so privileges a controversial interpretation of the social conditions of the period.
answer_choices.C: Although Beowulf fits well with the historical context of England in the late ninth through early eleventh centuries, it fits equally well with the historical context of England in the seventh and eighth centuries.
answer_choices.D: Although the claim of a late ninth- through early eleventh-century composition date for Beowulf has some plausibility, advocates for the claim have not compellingly addressed evidence suggesting an earlier date.

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it most accurately states the main idea of the text. The text explains that while a later composition date for Beowulf may seem plausible given the historical context, the linguistic evidence points to an earlier composition (seventh or even eighth century), and scholars favoring the later date have not provided adequate justification for ignoring the linguistic evidence.

questions.notes:
The following text is adapted from Oscar Wilde’s 1891 novel The Picture of Dorian Gray. Dorian Gray is taking his first look at a portrait that Hallward has painted of him.
Dorian passed listlessly in front of his picture and turned towards it. When he saw it he drew back, and his cheeks flushed for a moment with pleasure. A look of joy came into his eyes, as if he had recognized himself for the first time. He stood there motionless and in wonder, dimly conscious that Hallward was speaking to him, but not catching the meaning of his words. The sense of his own beauty came on him like a revelation. He had never felt it before.
questions.question: According to the text, what is true about Dorian?

answer_choices.A: He wants to know Hallward’s opinion of the portrait.
answer_choices.B: He is delighted by what he sees in the portrait.
answer_choices.C: He prefers portraits to other types of paintings.
answer_choices.D: He is uncertain of Hallward’s talent as an artist.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the text describes Dorian’s positive and enthralled reaction to seeing his portrait—his cheeks flush with pleasure and his eyes fill with joy—indicating that he is delighted by what he sees.

questions.notes: For centuries, the widespread acknowledgment of the involvement of the cerebellum—a dense brain structure in vertebrates—in coordinating motor control in humans has hindered recognition of other possible functions of the structure. Neuroscience research from the last two decades now suggests that the cerebellum regulates emotion and social behavior, and recent research by Ilaria Carta and colleagues has identified a pathway connecting the cerebellum to a center for motivation and reward processing known as the ventral tegmental area (VTA).
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

answer_choices.A: The recent verification of a pathway between the VTA and the cerebellum confirms the cerebellum’s long-suspected role in motor coordination.
answer_choices.B: Recent advances in the field of neuroscience have challenged widely accepted claims about the function of a pathway connecting the VTA and the cerebellum.
answer_choices.C: The cerebellum has primarily been thought to regulate motor functioning, but in recent years neuroscience researchers have been uncovering additional functions.
answer_choices.D: Technological limitations have historically hindered the study of the cerebellum, but the recent development of new technologies has led to greater insights into its functions.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because the text contrasts the traditional view that the cerebellum is solely involved in motor coordination with recent research suggesting it also plays a role in regulating emotion and social behavior, highlighting the discovery of a pathway linking it to the VTA.

questions.notes: In the United States, firms often seek incentives from municipal governments to expand to those municipalities. A team of political scientists hypothesized that municipalities are much more likely to respond to firms and offer incentives if expansions can be announced in time to benefit local elected officials than if they can’t. The team contacted officials in thousands of municipalities, inquiring about incentives for a firm looking to expand and indicating that the firm would announce its expansion on a date either just before or just after the next election.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the graph that weaken the team’s hypothesis?

answer_choices.A: A large majority of the municipalities that received an inquiry mentioning plans for an announcement before the next election didn’t respond to the inquiry.
answer_choices.B: The proportion of municipalities that responded to the inquiry or offered incentives didn’t substantially differ across the announcement timing conditions.
answer_choices.C: Only around half the municipalities that responded to inquiries mentioning plans for an announcement before the next election offered incentives.
answer_choices.D: Of the municipalities that received an inquiry mentioning plans for an announcement date after the next election, more than 1,200 didn’t respond and only around 100 offered incentives.

questions.rationale:
Choice B is the best answer. The lighter bars show what happened when the announcement was to come before the election, and the darker bars show what happened when the announcement was to come after the election. For all three of the outcomes, the light and dark bars are virtually the same, demonstrating that the announcement timing didn’t actually make a difference.

Choice A is incorrect. This accurately describes some data from the graph, but it doesn’t weaken the hypothesis. It doesn’t include the “announcement after election” data for comparison. Choice C is incorrect. This accurately describes some data from the graph, but it doesn’t weaken the hypothesis. It doesn’t include the “announcement after election” data for comparison. Choice D is incorrect. This accurately describes some data from the graph, but it doesn’t weaken the hypothesis. It doesn’t include the “announcement before election” data for comparison.

questions.notes: Although many transposons, DNA sequences that move within an organism’s genome through shuffling or duplication, have become corrupted and inactive over time, those from the long interspersed nuclear elements (LINE) family appear to remain active in the genomes of some species. In humans, they are functionally important within the hippocampus, a brain structure that supports complex cognitive processes. When the results of molecular analysis of two species of octopus—an animal known for its intelligence—were announced in 2022, the confirmation of a LINE transposon in Octopus vulgaris and Octopus bimaculoides genomes prompted researchers to hypothesize that that transposon family is tied to a species’ capacity for advanced cognition.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the researchers’ hypothesis?

answer_choices.A: The LINE transposon in O. vulgaris and O. bimaculoides genomes is active in an octopus brain structure that functions similarly to the human hippocampus.
answer_choices.B: The human genome contains multiple transposons from the LINE family that are all primarily active in the hippocampus.
answer_choices.C: A consistent number of copies of LINE transposons is present across the genomes of most octopus species, with few known corruptions.
answer_choices.D: O. vulgaris and O. bimaculoides have smaller brains than humans do relative to body size, but their genomes contain sequences from a wider variety of transposon families.

questions.rationale:
Choice A is the best answer. The text says that LINE transposons are important in the human hippocampus, which supports complex cognition. If the LINE transposon found in octopuses is active in a similar part of their brain, that would suggest that LINE transposons support complex cognition in octopuses too, which in turn supports the hypothesis that LINE transposons are linked to advanced cognition in general.

Choice B is incorrect. This choice doesn’t support the hypothesis. It doesn’t include anything about how LINE transposons function in species other than humans.

Choice C is incorrect. This choice doesn’t support the hypothesis. It doesn’t include anything about how the LINE transposon in octopuses might support advanced cognition.

Choice D is incorrect. This choice doesn’t support the hypothesis. It doesn’t include anything about how the LINE transposon in octopuses might support advanced cognition.

questions.notes: To make sure they got the nutrition they needed while in space, the astronauts of NASA’s Gemini missions were given menus for three meals a day (meals A, B, and C) on a four-day rotating schedule. Looking at the sample of food items from these menus, a student notes that on day 1, the menu included ______blank
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the statement?

answer_choices.A: shrimp cocktail for meal B.
answer_choices.B: hot cocoa for meal C.
answer_choices.C: sugar cookie cubes for meal B.
answer_choices.D: chicken and vegetables for meal A.

questions.rationale:
Choice C is the best answer because it most effectively uses data from the table to complete the statement. The table shows that on day 1, the menu for NASA’s Gemini missions included sugar cookie cubes for meal B.

Choice A is incorrect because according to the table, shrimp cocktail was served on day 4, not day 1; moreover, the item was served for meal C, not meal B, as this choice claims.

Choice B is incorrect because according to the table, hot cocoa was served on day 3, not on day 1; moreover, the item was served for meal A, not for meal C, as this choice claims.

Choice D is incorrect because according to the table, chicken and vegetables were served on day 2, not on day 1; moreover, the item was served for meal B, not for meal A, as this choice claims.

questions.notes: High levels of public uncertainty about which economic policies a country will adopt can make planning difficult for businesses, but measures of such uncertainty have not tended to be very detailed. Recently, however, economist Sandile Hlatshwayo analyzed trends in news reports to derive measures not only for general economic policy uncertainty but also for uncertainty related to specific areas of economic policy, like tax or trade policy. One revelation of her work is that a general measure may not fully reflect uncertainty about specific areas of policy, as in the case of the United Kingdom, where general economic policy uncertainty ______blank
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to illustrate the claim?

answer_choices.A: aligned closely with uncertainty about tax and public spending policy in 2005 but differed from uncertainty about tax and public spending policy by a large amount in 2009.
answer_choices.B: was substantially lower than uncertainty about tax and public spending policy each year from 2005 to 2010.
answer_choices.C: reached its highest level between 2005 and 2010 in the same year that uncertainty about trade policy and tax and public spending policy reached their lowest levels.
answer_choices.D: was substantially lower than uncertainty about trade policy in 2005 and substantially higher than uncertainty about trade policy in 2010.

questions.rationale:
Choice D is the best answer because it uses data from the graph to effectively illustrate the text’s claim about general economic policy uncertainty in the United Kingdom. The graph presents values for economic policy uncertainty in tax and public spending policy, trade policy, and general economic policy in the UK from 2005 to 2010. The graph shows that in 2005, the value for general economic policy uncertainty (approximately 90) was substantially lower than the value for uncertainty about trade policy specifically (approximately 160). It also shows that in 2010, the value for general economic policy uncertainty (approximately 120) was substantially higher than the value for uncertainty about trade policy (approximately 70). The substantial differences between these values in 2005 and 2010 support the claim that a general measure may not fully reflect uncertainty about specific areas of policy.

Choice A is incorrect because the graph shows that the level of general economic policy uncertainty was similar to the level of uncertainty about tax and public spending policy in both 2005 (with values of approximately 90 and 100, respectively) and 2009 (with values of approximately 80 and 75, respectively). Choice B is incorrect because the graph shows that general economic policy uncertainty was higher than uncertainty about tax and public spending policy in 2006, 2007, and 2009, not that it was lower each year from 2005 to 2010. Choice C is incorrect because the graph shows that general economic policy uncertainty reached its highest level in 2010, which was when uncertainty about tax and public spending policy also reached its highest level, not its lowest level.

questions.notes: Many archaeologists will tell you that categorizing excavated fragments of pottery by style, period, and what objects they belong to relies not only on standard criteria, but also on instinct developed over years of practice. In a recent study, however, researchers trained a deep-learning computer model on thousands of images of pottery fragments and found that it could categorize them as accurately as a team of expert archaeologists. Some archaeologists have expressed concern that they might be replaced by such computer models, but the researchers claim that outcome is highly unlikely.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the researchers’ claim?

answer_choices.A: In the researchers’ study, the model was able to categorize the pottery fragments much more quickly than the archaeologists could.
answer_choices.B: In the researchers’ study, neither the model nor the archeologists were able to accurately categorize all the pottery fragments that were presented.
answer_choices.C: A survey of archaeologists showed that categorizing pottery fragments limits the amount of time they can dedicate to other important tasks that only human experts can do.
answer_choices.D: A survey of archaeologists showed that few of them received dedicated training in how to properly categorize pottery fragments.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because it presents a finding that, if true, would support the researchers’ claim that archaeologists are unlikely to be replaced by computer models. If categorizing pottery fragments consumes so much of an archaeologist's time that it limits their ability to perform other tasks that require human expertise, then even if a computer can categorize fragments as accurately as a human, it does not replace the broader range of work that archaeologists perform.

questions.notes: Scientists have long believed that giraffes are mostly silent and communicate only visually with one another. But biologist Angela Stöger and her team analyzed hundreds of hours of recordings of giraffes in three European zoos and found that giraffes make a very low-pitched humming sound. The researchers claim that the giraffes use these sounds to communicate when it’s not possible for them to signal one another visually.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Stöger and her team’s claim?

answer_choices.A: Giraffes have an excellent sense of vision and can see in color.
answer_choices.B: The giraffes only produced the humming sounds at night when they couldn’t see one another.
answer_choices.C: Wild giraffes have never been recorded making humming sounds.
answer_choices.D: Researchers observed other animals in European zoos humming.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because if giraffes produce humming sounds exclusively during times when visual communication is compromised (such as at night), it directly supports the claim that these sounds are used as an alternative communication method when they cannot see one another.

questions.notes: Black beans (Phaseolus vulgaris) are a nutritionally dense food, but they are difficult to digest in part because of their high levels of soluble fiber and compounds like raffinose. They also contain antinutrients like tannins and trypsin inhibitors, which interfere with the body’s ability to extract nutrients from foods. In a research article, Marisela Granito and Glenda Álvarez from Simón Bolívar University in Venezuela claim that inducing fermentation of black beans using lactic acid bacteria improves the digestibility of the beans and makes them more nutritious.
questions.question: Which finding from Granito and Álvarez’s research, if true, would most directly support their claim?

answer_choices.A: When cooked, fermented beans contained significantly more trypsin inhibitors and tannins but significantly less soluble fiber and raffinose than nonfermented beans.
answer_choices.B: Fermented beans contained significantly less soluble fiber and raffinose than nonfermented beans, and when cooked, the fermented beans also displayed a significant reduction in trypsin inhibitors and tannins.
answer_choices.C: When the fermented beans were analyzed, they were found to contain two microorganisms, Lactobacillus casei and Lactobacillus plantarum, that are theorized to increase the amount of nitrogen absorbed by the gut after eating beans.
answer_choices.D: Both fermented and nonfermented black beans contained significantly fewer trypsin inhibitors and tannins after being cooked at high pressure.

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because it demonstrates that fermentation leads to reductions in both the indigestible soluble fiber and raffinose as well as in the antinutrients (trypsin inhibitors and tannins) when the beans are cooked, directly supporting the claim that fermentation improves digestibility and nutrition.

questions.notes: The novelist Toni Morrison was the first Black woman to work as an editor at the publishing company Random House, from 1967 to 1983. A scholar asserts that one of Morrison’s likely aims during her time as an editor was to strengthen the presence of Black writers on the list of Random House’s published authors.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most strongly support the scholar’s claim?

answer_choices.A: The percentage of authors published by Random House who were Black rose in the early 1970s and stabilized throughout the decade.
answer_choices.B: Black authors who were interviewed in the 1980s and 1990s were highly likely to cite Toni Morrison’s novels as a principal influence on their work.
answer_choices.C: The novels written by Toni Morrison that were published after 1983 sold significantly more copies and received wider critical acclaim than the novels she wrote that were published before 1983.
answer_choices.D: Works that were edited by Toni Morrison during her time at Random House displayed stylistic characteristics that distinguished them from works that were not edited by Morrison.

questions.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because if Random House published a higher percentage of works by Black authors during Morrison’s tenure, that would support the scholar’s claim that Morrison aimed to strengthen the presence of Black writers on the company’s list.

questions.notes: “Ghosts of the Old Year” is an early 1900s poem by James Weldon Johnson. In the poem, the speaker describes experiencing an ongoing cycle of anticipation followed by regretful reflection: ______blank
questions.question: Which quotation from “Ghosts of the Old Year” most effectively illustrates the claim?

answer_choices.A: “What does this brazen tongue declare, / That falling on the midnight air / Brings to my heart a sense of care / Akin to fright?”
answer_choices.B: “The snow has ceased its fluttering flight, / The wind sunk to a whisper light, / An ominous stillness fills the night, / A pause—a hush.”
answer_choices.C: “It tells of many a squandered day, / Of slighted gems and treasured clay, / Of precious stores not laid away, / Of fields unreaped.”
answer_choices.D: “And so the years go swiftly by, / Each, coming, brings ambitions high, / And each, departing, leaves a sigh / Linked to the past.”

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because it effectively captures the ongoing cycle of anticipation (each new year brings high ambitions) and subsequent regret or reflection (each departing year leaves a sigh linked to the past), illustrating the claim.

questions.notes: Given that stars and planets initially form from the same gas and dust in space, some astronomers have posited that host stars (such as the Sun) and their planets (such as those in our solar system) are composed of the same materials, with the planets containing equal or smaller quantities of the materials that make up the host star. This idea is also supported by evidence that rocky planets in our solar system are composed of some of the same materials as the Sun.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly weaken the astronomers’ claim?

answer_choices.A: Most stars are made of hydrogen and helium, but when cooled they are revealed to contain small amounts of iron and silicate.
answer_choices.B: A nearby host star is observed to contain the same proportion of hydrogen and helium as that of the Sun.
answer_choices.C: Evidence emerges that the amount of iron in some rocky planets is considerably higher than the amount in their host star.
answer_choices.D: The method for determining the composition of rocky planets is discovered to be less effective when used to analyze other kinds of planets.

questions.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because if rocky planets contain significantly more iron than their host stars, it directly contradicts the claim that planets are composed of the same materials as their host stars in equal or smaller quantities.

questions.notes: The Souls of Black Folk is a 1903 book by W.E.B. Du Bois...
questions.question: Which quotation from The Souls of Black Folk most effectively illustrates the claim?

answer_choices.A: [Black folk music] still remains as the singular spiritual heritage of the nation and the greatest gift of the Negro people.
answer_choices.B: Ever since I was a child these songs have stirred me strangely...
answer_choices.C: Caricature has sought again to spoil the quaint beauty of the music...
answer_choices.D: The songs are indeed the siftings of centuries...

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because the quotation from The Souls of Black Folk illustrates the claim that Du Bois felt a sense of cultural recognition when he heard Black folk songs. Even though they originated in the South, he knew the songs 'as of me and of mine.'

questions.notes: In the 1970s, a roughly 60,000-year-old piece of hyena bone...
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly weaken the underlined claim?

answer_choices.A: Parallel lines are a common feature in modern humans’ early systems...
answer_choices.B: More than nine approximately parallel notches made with a different stone tool...
answer_choices.C: It would have taken careful effort to make evenly spaced lines on bone...
answer_choices.D: Decorative art discovered at another Neanderthal site in western France...

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. If unevenly spaced parallel lines were found on decorative art at another Neanderthal site, it would suggest that the hyena bone is decorative too—not a counting tool.

questions.notes: Hedda Gabler is an 1890 play by Henrik Ibsen...
questions.question: Which quotation from a translation of Hedda Gabler most effectively illustrates the claim?

answer_choices.A: Then what in heaven’s name would you have me do with myself?
answer_choices.B: I want for once in my life to have power to mould a human destiny.
answer_choices.C: Then I, poor creature, have no sort of power over you?
answer_choices.D: Faithful to your principles, now and for ever! Ah, that is how a man should be!

questions.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because Hedda says she wants 'to have power to mould a human destiny,' showing her desire to influence another person’s fate.

questions.notes: A member of the Otomi, an Indigenous people in Central Mexico...
questions.question: Which quotation from an art critic most directly challenges the underlined claim in the text?

answer_choices.A: Although a number of ancient Indigenous artistic traditions pictured human forms in profile...
answer_choices.B: In A History of Mexico, the synthesis of ancient and modernist traditions functions...
answer_choices.C: Many critics focus on Indigenous influences in A History of Mexico...
answer_choices.D: While A History of Mexico features modernist motifs, it relies primarily on angular human forms...

questions.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. It argues that the use of Maya-style human profiles invites classification as Indigenous art, challenging the idea that the work resists classification by cultural identity.

questions.notes: Art collectives often involve collaboration, which can be difficult for artists used to working independently. A journalist claims this loss of individual control can be challenging.
questions.student_goal: Identify which interview quote best supports the journalist's claim about difficulties in collaborative artistic work.

answer_choices.A: The first collective I joined included many amazingly talented artists, and we enjoyed each other’s company, but because we had a hard time sharing credit and responsibility for our work, the collective didn’t last.
answer_choices.B: We work together, but that doesn’t mean that individual projects are equally the work of all of us. Many of our projects are primarily the responsibility of whoever originally proposed the work to the group.
answer_choices.C: Having worked as a member of a collective for several years, it’s sometimes hard to recall what it was like to work alone without the collective’s support. But that support encourages my individual expression rather than limits it.
answer_choices.D: Sometimes an artist from outside the collective will choose to collaborate with us on a project, but all of those projects fit within the larger themes of the work the collective does on its own.

questions.notes: Bessie Coleman defied gender norms through her public image. A researcher suggests this was intentional.
questions.student_goal: Find the quote that most directly supports the idea that Coleman intentionally challenged social norms.

answer_choices.A: For her air shows, Coleman frequently used the Curtiss JN-4, or ‘Jenny,’ which at that time was one of the most well-known types of planes.
answer_choices.B: While Coleman was beloved by spectators for her charisma, she had a more complicated relationship with her managers and staff, who at times found her behavior too impulsive and demanding.
answer_choices.C: Coleman once considered leaving her career as a stunt pilot to focus her efforts on giving speeches, which she felt would better support her public image.
answer_choices.D: Although female pilots were typically expected to wear traditional but impractical attire that included dresses or skirts, photographs of Coleman show her wearing pants and leather jackets.

questions.notes: A fashion design student claims Patrick Kelly was inspired by female relatives to use decorative buttons.
questions.student_goal: Choose the historian's quote that best supports the student’s claim about Kelly's childhood influences.

answer_choices.A: Although some of the assortments of buttons appear to be mismatched pieces scattered randomly throughout Kelly’s dresses, his most famous designs feature carefully crafted patterns of matching buttons.
answer_choices.B: Many of Kelly’s contemporaries were inspired by his designs to incorporate buttons, as well as zippers and snaps, as decorative items in their work.
answer_choices.C: Kelly’s grandmother, who would repair clothing when he was a child, frequently added mismatched buttons to the clothes to draw attention away from any flaws in the garments.
answer_choices.D: Kelly was destined to be a designer from a young age: he learned how to sew clothing from his aunt Bertha, and his love of drawing was developed by his mother.

questions.notes: In Wilde’s An Ideal Husband, Lady Chiltern is perceived as extremely virtuous and unforgiving.
questions.student_goal: Select the quote that best illustrates both Lady Chiltern’s virtuousness and her lack of mercy.

answer_choices.A: Lady Chiltern is a woman of the very highest principles, I am glad to say. I am a little too old now, myself, to trouble about setting a good example, but I always admire people who do.
answer_choices.B: Do you know, [Lady Chiltern], I don’t mind your talking morality a bit. Morality is simply the attitude we adopt towards people whom we personally dislike.
answer_choices.C: [Lady Chiltern] does not know what weakness or temptation is. I am of clay like other men. She stands apart as good women do—pitiless in her perfection—cold and stern and without mercy.
answer_choices.D: Lady Chiltern, you are a sensible woman, the most sensible woman in London, the most sensible woman I know.

questions.notes: Hip-hop pedagogy improves student interest and engagement. Researchers say it supports success by boosting classroom enthusiasm.
questions.student_goal: Select the finding that best supports the claim about student interest and engagement.

answer_choices.A: Students tend to be more enthusiastic about rap music than they are about hip-hop music.
answer_choices.B: Students who are highly interested in social justice issues typically don’t sign up for courses that incorporate hip-hop and rap music.
answer_choices.C: Educators report that they enjoy teaching courses that involve hip-hop and rap music more than teaching courses that don’t.
answer_choices.D: Courses that incorporate hip-hop and rap music are among the courses with the highest enrollment and attendance rates.

questions.notes: Gilman’s poem 'The Rock and the Sea' portrays the rock as trying to limit the sea’s power.
questions.student_goal: Select the quote that most clearly shows the rock confronting and attempting to restrain the sea.

answer_choices.A: I am the Rock. Black midnight falls; / The terrible breakers rise like walls; / With curling lips and gleaming teeth / They plunge and tear at my bones beneath.
answer_choices.B: I am the Sea. I hold the land / As one holds an apple in his hand, / Hold it fast with sleepless eyes, / Watching the continents sink and rise.
answer_choices.C: I am the Rock, presumptuous Sea! / I am set to encounter thee. / Angry and loud or gentle and still, / I am set here to limit thy power, and I will!
answer_choices.D: I am the Sea. The earth I sway; / Granite to me is potter’s clay; / Under the touch of my careless waves / It rises in turrets and sinks in caves.

questions.notes: Marta Coll and colleagues’ 2010 Mediterranean Sea biodiversity census reported approximately 17,000 species, nearly double the number reported in Carlo Bianchi and Carla Morri’s 2000 census—a difference only partly attributable to the description of new invertebrate species...
questions.student_goal: Determine the logical conclusion based on contrasting biodiversity census results and researcher methodology.

answer_choices.A: Coll and colleagues reported a much higher number of species than Bianchi and Morri did largely due to the inclusion of invertebrate species that had not been described at the time of Bianchi and Morri’s census.
answer_choices.B: some differences observed in microorganisms may have been treated as variations within species by Bianchi and Morri but treated as indicative of distinct species by Coll and colleagues.
answer_choices.C: Bianchi and Morri may have been less sensitive to the degree of morphological variation displayed within a typical species of microorganism than Coll and colleagues were.
answer_choices.D: the absence of clarity regarding how to differentiate among species of microorganisms may have resulted in Coll and colleagues underestimating the number of microorganism species.

questions.notes: In her 2021 article “Throwaway History: Towards a Historiography of Ephemera,” Anne Garner discusses John Johnson, a collector of items intended to be discarded. His collection was initially viewed as worthless but later acquired by Oxford’s Bodleian Library in 1968 due to its historical value.
questions.student_goal: Determine what Johnson’s example suggests about changing scholarly attitudes.

answer_choices.A: demonstrate the difficulties faced by contemporary historians in conducting research at the Bodleian Library without access to ephemera.
answer_choices.B: represent the challenge of incorporating examples of ephemera into the collections of libraries and other scholarly institutions.
answer_choices.C: lend support to arguments by historians and other researchers who continue to assert that ephemera holds no value for scholars.
answer_choices.D: illustrate both the relatively low scholarly regard in which ephemera was once held and the later recognition of ephemera’s possible utility.

questions.notes: Researchers examined how interruptions affect people’s enjoyment of experiences. They found that interruptions can increase enjoyment of pleasant experiences and hypothesized the opposite for unpleasant ones. In a study, participants listened to construction noise interrupted by silence breaks or not.
questions.student_goal: Infer researchers’ expectations for the effect of interruptions on unpleasant experiences.

answer_choices.A: find the disruptions more irritating as time went on.
answer_choices.B: rate the listening experience as more negative than those whose listening experience was uninterrupted.
answer_choices.C: rate the experience of listening to construction noise as lasting for less time than it actually lasted.
answer_choices.D: perceive the volume of the construction noise as growing softer over time.

questions.notes: Shakespeare’s tragedies are widely appreciated today for their broad themes, but understanding his history plays requires deep knowledge of English history. Romeo and Juliet remains accessible due to its universal themes.
questions.student_goal: Compare the accessibility of Shakespeare’s tragedies and history plays to modern audiences.

answer_choices.A: many theatergoers and readers today are likely to find Shakespeare’s history plays less engaging than the tragedies.
answer_choices.B: some of Shakespeare’s tragedies are more relevant to today’s audiences than twentieth-century plays.
answer_choices.C: Romeo and Juliet is the most thematically accessible of all Shakespeare’s tragedies.
answer_choices.D: experts in English history tend to prefer Shakespeare’s history plays to his other works.

questions.notes: In the 1800s, Euro-American farmers in the northeastern U.S. used farming techniques similar to those of the Haudenosaunee, despite not having direct contact with Haudenosaunee farms. This suggests indirect transmission of knowledge.
questions.student_goal: Determine the most logical explanation for how Euro-American farmers adopted Haudenosaunee techniques.

answer_choices.A: those farmers learned the techniques from other people who were more directly influenced by Haudenosaunee practices.
answer_choices.B: the crops typically cultivated by Euro-American farmers in the northeastern United States were not well suited to Haudenosaunee farming techniques.
answer_choices.C: Haudenosaunee farming techniques were widely used in regions outside the northeastern United States.
answer_choices.D: Euro-American farmers only began to recognize the benefits of Haudenosaunee farming techniques late in the nineteenth century.

questions.notes: A management research team found that workplace interruptions, though commonly viewed as reducing productivity, can increase employees’ sense of belonging and satisfaction.
questions.student_goal: Assess the implications of research findings about workplace interruptions.

answer_choices.A: the interpersonal benefits of some interruptions in the workplace may offset the perceived negative effects.
answer_choices.B: in order to maximize productivity, employers should be willing to interrupt employees frequently throughout the day.
answer_choices.C: most employees avoid interrupting colleagues because they don’t appreciate being interrupted themselves.
answer_choices.D: in order to cultivate an ideal workplace environment, interruptions of work should be discouraged.

questions.notes: Polynesians cultivated sweet potatoes before any known contact with South America. DNA evidence shows the varieties in Polynesia diverged from South American types over 100,000 years ago—long before humans settled Polynesia.
questions.student_goal: Determine the most plausible conclusion about how sweet potatoes arrived in Polynesia.

answer_choices.A: the cultivation of the sweet potato in Polynesia likely predates its cultivation in South America.
answer_choices.B: Polynesian peoples likely acquired the sweet potato from South American peoples only within the last three thousand years.
answer_choices.C: human activity likely played no role in the introduction of the sweet potato in Polynesia.
answer_choices.D: Polynesian sweet potato varieties likely descend from a single South American variety that was domesticated, not wild.

questions.notes: Ecologists studied methane emissions in tanks with different aquatic plants. Tanks with underwater plants like watermilfoil released less methane than tanks with surface plants like duckweed or algae.
questions.student_goal: Determine the environmental impact of different types of aquatic vegetation.

answer_choices.A: the presence of some kinds of underwater plants like watermilfoil helps prevent methane from escaping shallow lakes and ponds.
answer_choices.B: shallow lakes and ponds release more methane than deeper bodies of water because shallow bodies of water usually have more plants than deep bodies of water do.
answer_choices.C: shallow lakes and ponds are more likely to contain algae than to contain either watermilfoil or duckweed.
answer_choices.D: having a mix of algae, underwater plants, and floating plants is the best way to reduce the amount of methane in shallow lakes and ponds.

questions.notes: Zelda Fitzgerald, while often viewed as an influence on her husband F. Scott Fitzgerald’s writing, also authored her own significant works. Scholars frequently overlook her literary contributions.
questions.student_goal: Assess how scholarly views of Zelda Fitzgerald may misrepresent her legacy.

answer_choices.A: overlook the many other factors that motivated F. Scott to write.
answer_choices.B: risk misrepresenting the full range of Zelda’s contributions to literature.
answer_choices.C: may draw inaccurate conclusions about how F. Scott and Zelda viewed each other’s works.
answer_choices.D: tend to read the works of F. Scott and Zelda in an overly autobiographical light.

questions.notes: Musicians have tried the 'pay as you wish' pricing model. One band earned less than expected, while another artist earned more than expected using the same model.
questions.student_goal: Evaluate the variability in financial success of the 'pay as you wish' pricing strategy.

answer_choices.A: prove financially successful for some musicians but disappointing for others.
answer_choices.B: hold greater financial appeal for bands than for individual musicians.
answer_choices.C: cause most musicians who use the model to lower the suggested prices of their songs and albums over time.
answer_choices.D: more strongly reflect differences in certain musicians’ popularity than traditional pricing models do.

questions.notes: Observations of orangutans standing on two legs in trees suggest that bipedalism may have originated in tree-dwelling ancestors, not just ground-dwelling ones.
questions.student_goal: Explore an alternate theory of the evolutionary origins of human bipedalism.

answer_choices.A: bipedalism evolved because it was advantageous to a tree-dwelling ancestor of humans.
answer_choices.B: bipedalism must have evolved simultaneously with knuckle-walking and tree-climbing.
answer_choices.C: moving between the ground and the trees would have been difficult without bipedalism.
answer_choices.D: a knuckle-walking human ancestor could have easily moved bipedally in trees.

questions.notes: After copyright expired in 2014, Sherlock Holmes stories became more accessible for adaptations, leading to predictions of an increase in new versions.
questions.student_goal: Understand the impact of copyright expiration on literary adaptations.

answer_choices.A: Doyle’s original stories will become hard to find.
answer_choices.B: people will become more interested in detective stories than they were in the 1800s.
answer_choices.C: producing adaptations will become easier and less expensive.
answer_choices.D: the former copyright holders of Doyle’s estate will return fees they collected.

questions.notes: Pied flycatcher nestlings showed a preference for local bird song dialects. Since song preference affects mate selection, this may influence reproductive patterns.
questions.student_goal: Determine the likely future behavior influenced by early dialect preference in songbirds.

answer_choices.A: F. hypoleuca nestlings’ preference for their own dialect likely disappears as they mature to promote socialization between different F. hypoleuca populations.
answer_choices.B: F. hypoleuca nestlings who show an early preference for their own dialect are likely to receive more food from their caretakers than nestlings who show no preferences among any F. hypoleuca dialects.
answer_choices.C: F. hypoleuca nestlings’ preference for their own dialect likely drives them when they mature to reproduce with other F. hypoleuca from local rather than nonlocal populations.
answer_choices.D: F. hypoleuca nestlings show a preference for both local F. hypoleuca dialects and the songs of other local songbirds over the songs of nonlocal birds of any species.

questions.notes: To test whether holding elected office affects behavior, researchers need control groups. Since elections aren’t random, finding equivalent non-officeholders is hard.
questions.student_goal: Identify a challenge in designing political behavior studies with proper control groups.

answer_choices.A: struggle to find valid data about the behavior of politicians who do not currently hold office.
answer_choices.B: can only conduct valid studies with people who have previously held office rather than people who presently hold office.
answer_choices.C: should select a control group of people who differ from office holders in several significant ways.
answer_choices.D: will find it difficult to identify a group of people who can function as an appropriate control group for their studies.

questions.notes: Researchers tested the effect of physical contact on perceived value. Participants who could touch a mug and toy were willing to pay more than those who could not.
questions.student_goal: Determine the impact of sensory interaction on consumer valuation of products.

answer_choices.A: people who mainly shop online probably spend more money every month than people who mainly shop in person do.
answer_choices.B: in-person shopping may make products seem more valuable than they seem if only viewed online.
answer_choices.C: retailers with in-person and online stores should charge the same price for a given product in both places.
answer_choices.D: online retailers may be able to raise the prices they charge for products that are only available online.

questions.notes: Bertolt Brecht believed theater should provoke intellectual rather than emotional responses. Caryl Churchill’s play Cloud 9 follows this by focusing on patriarchy and colonialism and placing audiences at a distance.
questions.student_goal: Understand how Churchill’s theatrical approach aligns with Brecht’s goals.

answer_choices.A: focus on the characters’ beliefs about social and political issues as revealed by the characters’ actions.
answer_choices.B: reflect on social and political phenomena not directly related to patriarchy and colonialism.
answer_choices.C: recognize pertinent social and political parallels between Germany during Brecht’s time and England at the time when Churchill was writing Cloud 9.
answer_choices.D: be dispassionate as they think critically about the social and political questions raised by the play.

questions.notes: Scholars previously believed the Maya lacked marketplaces due to underestimating ecological diversity in Maya regions. They assumed everyone produced similar crops, removing the need to trade.
questions.student_goal: Understand how ecological assumptions influenced historical interpretations of Maya trade practices.

answer_choices.A: marketplaces likely would not have attracted many traders from outside the regions controlled by the Maya.
answer_choices.B: farming practices would have been largely the same throughout Maya lands even if the crops people produced varied significantly.
answer_choices.C: marketplaces would not have enabled Maya people to acquire many products different from those they already produced.
answer_choices.D: farmers would trade agricultural products only if they had already produced enough to meet their own needs.

questions.notes: Fan cells in the brain are required for forming associative memories and need dopamine to activate. Dopamine is released in response to rewards.
questions.student_goal: Understand how dopamine and rewards affect the formation of associative memories.

answer_choices.A: decrease an individual’s capacity to utilize dopamine.
answer_choices.B: increase an individual’s capacity to recognize differences between unrelated things.
answer_choices.C: increase an individual’s capacity to form associative memories.
answer_choices.D: decrease an individual’s capacity to create fan cells.

questions.notes: Military veterans hold a disproportionately large share of civilian government jobs. One explanation is that veterans are familiar with the bureaucratic structures found in these jobs.
questions.student_goal: Identify the reason veterans might be drawn to civilian government jobs.

answer_choices.A: makes civilian government jobs especially appealing to military veterans.
answer_choices.B: alters the typical relationship between military service and subsequent career preferences.
answer_choices.C: encourages nonveterans applying for civilian government jobs to consider military service instead.
answer_choices.D: increases the number of civilian government jobs that require some amount of military experience to perform.

questions.notes: Mars’s crust was thought to be mostly basalt from cooled magma. But data revealed high silica concentrations, suggesting more complex geological history.
questions.student_goal: Understand what new silica data implies about the formation of Mars’s crust.

answer_choices.A: the information about silica concentrations collected by the spacecraft is likely more reliable than the silica information gleaned from infrared wavelengths detected from Mars’s surface.
answer_choices.B: high silica concentrations on Mars likely formed from a different process than that which formed the crusts of other planets.
answer_choices.C: having a clearer understanding of the composition of Mars’s crust and the processes by which it formed will provide more insight into how Earth’s crust formed.
answer_choices.D: Mars’s crust likely formed as a result of other major geological events in addition to the cooling of a magma ocean.
